answer_html: With a different initial condition the other equilibrium y=-1/2 would be approached.)
answer_latex:
With a
different initial condition the other equilibrium \emph{y=-1/2} would be
approached.)
hints_html: When \(y(t)\) no longer changes, what does that imply for \(\frac{dy}{dt}\)?
hints_latex: When $y(t)$ no longer changes, what does that imply for $\frac{dy}{dt}$?
hints_raw: When <math> y(t) </math> no longer changes, what does that imply for <math>\frac{dy}{dt}</math>?
question: 1 (h)
sols_html:
Saying that y(t) does not change any more is the same as saying that y(t) is constant. A function is constant if its derivative \(\frac{dy}{dt}\) is equal to 0. So we look for values of \(y\) that satisfy \(0=1-4y^2\). This equation only holds for \(y=\pm 1/2\).

Hence the the right answer is v.

(Note: The answer y=-1/2 is not a choice here because of the initial condition y(0)=0. The solution of the differential equation starts at y=0 and then increases to y=1/2. With a different initial condition the other equilibrium y=-1/2 would be approached.)
sols_latex:
Saying that \emph{y(t)} does not change any more is the same as saying
that \emph{y(t)} is constant. A function is constant if its derivative
$\frac{dy}{dt}$ is equal to 0. So we look for values of $y$ that satisfy
$0=1-4y^2$. This equation only holds for $y=\pm 1/2$.

Hence the the right answer is \textbf{v}.

(Note: The answer \emph{y=-1/2} is not a choice here because of the
initial condition \emph{y(0)=0}. The solution of the differential
equation starts at \emph{y=0} and then increases to \emph{y=1/2}. With a
different initial condition the other equilibrium \emph{y=-1/2} would be
approached.)
sols_raw:
Saying that ''y(t)'' does not change any more is the same as saying that ''y(t)'' is constant. A function is constant if its derivative <math>\frac{dy}{dt}</math> is equal to 0. So we look for values of <math>y</math> that satisfy <math>\ 0=1-4y^2</math>. This equation only holds for <math>y=\pm 1/2 </math>. 

Hence the the right answer is '''v'''.

(Note: The answer ''y=-1/2'' is not a choice here because of the initial condition ''y(0)=0''. The solution of the differential equation starts at ''y=0'' and then increases to ''y=1/2''. With a different initial condition the other equilibrium ''y=-1/2'' would be approached.)
statement_html:
Multiple Choice Question: Exactly ONE of the answers provided is correct. There is no partial credit in this questions.

Consider the differential equation

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dt} = 1-4y^2\end{aligned}\]

and initial condition \(y(0) = 0.\) After a long time (when \(y\) no longer changes), the value of \(y\) is

i. \(y = 0\)

ii. \(y = 1\)

iii. \(y = 1/4\)

iv. \(y = 4\)

v. \(y = 1/2\)
statement_raw:
''Multiple Choice Question: Exactly ONE of the answers provided is correct. There is no partial credit in this questions.''

Consider the differential equation
:<math> \frac{dy}{dt} = 1-4y^2 </math>
and initial condition <math> y(0) = 0.</math> After a long time (when <math>y</math> no longer changes), the value of <math>y</math> is

:''i.'' <math> y = 0 </math>

:''ii.'' <math> y = 1 </math>

:''iii.'' <math> y = 1/4 </math>

:''iv.'' <math> y = 4 </math>

:''v.'' <math> y = 1/2 </math>
